div.p:
No indeed my sprightly Fanny I don't think you "a very
saucy Girl" but a very good Physician and kind friend - I will not
pay so good high a compliment to my own temper as to say that
I heard your Sentence without Emotion or so bad a one to your
Judgement & to conceal the full Effect it had upon my Mind.
But do me the justice to believe that I never for an instant
doubted arraigned your Decision; ; in short I believe instead
of pressing my thoughts into fine Sentences I had better tell
you the facts without any further preamble - first then
know that the unfortunate scenes are devoted to the flames
saving one which has been reserved for a more lingering though
not less ignominious fate; being previously streched upon a
catgut Rack it was bored through with a sharp instrument &
having a head to protect the fingers of the unfeeling Executionioner
then clipt by slow degrees with a pair of Enormous Shears till
at length after repeated Effort it was wrought into the pattern
of a cap in which degraded form it for the present exists -
Tyrant art thou satisfied ? - So much for the effect of your
cruelty now for the honor of of your medical Skill
I can safely swear that you have cured me of the Manic of
Play Writing at least for the Winter Season, but you know such
diseases when they attack the Body instead of the Mind usually
return at Spring and fade so that I cannot depend upon a radi
-cal radical Cure; ; In case of a second Eruption I'm sure my good friend
will Administer the same Medicines or more violent one's ones if the
disease should prove obstinate - Perhaps I am not quite intelli
-gible intelligible , but God forbid that for the sake of being so I should tran-
-slate translate the french Word I have ventured to make use of .-
What are you going to Wimpole Street again, I consider this
as a kind of second parting; and I shan't hear from you and you'll
quite forget me! ! and I shall be all alone in Ireland! ! your gay
entertaining companions will rival the grave - sedate - young
lady Alack and a well a day! ! what will become of her? -
Oh that I could bribe Fosbrooke to take my part & keep me
in your Mind will you ever talk, will you ever think of your
Edge'? let me drawers, let my bed, my stool any thing stand for
me - How am I to praise Fossè , as we used to call her
perhaps she won't do as much for me, well then tell her she's
very ungrateful for that I thought her a very good natured
chearful, sprightly giddy Girl - Oh I have a thousand Questions
to ask her, tell her that I beg she will write to me and tell
me how she left all things, living & being at Derby , how all old
School Mates do particularly Blakeway & Hodson, how many
hundred Scrapes Emmeline has been in since we parted
what party she is in &c &c - and pray ask her if I was a
grave sedate young Lady at Mrs.. Latiffiere's ; Has she forgot our
leaping off the top Scaffold at the hazard of our own necks, of our
noses at least, and our having the fools cap on for walking
on the Rails of the Stairs going to the Drawing Room & Miss
Ford's popping out upon us and crying So Ladies! and a thousand
other pretty pranks she'll divert you with up in the Corner
by the fireplace where you and I have Chattered many a live-
long livelong hour - Au reste she can chatter as fast as either of us
and giggle faster, you'll like her pour passer le temps vastly
I think she is not unlike Miss H. in person. - But you will
tell me all about her when you come to me again Oh and when
will that be? ? Pray don't forget me to Penelope; I hope she will
sometimes think and make you think of me - Is Cave
still at School? ? indeed I think just as you do of her - but
the next time you ask my opinion don't tell me your's
first - what's become of Lushington and her comment
pouvez dire comme cela Mààm selle! Poor Nimbhard!
If I live a thousand years I shall never forget her coming
up to me when I was perched up in the middle of
the Room upon a high stool, when it was Sin to approach
and Death to pity one she came up & whispered ne pleurez
pas ma chere Edgeworth there was more true goodness of heart
& friendship in that simple Sentence than I perhaps shall
often meet with from more sentimental friends, if ever
I meet her again I'll tell her so - Poor Girl! I do love
her for it - apropos what was my Crime, for to this hour
I don't know, Mrs. D. thought I was laughing at her didn't
she? I'm sure I was so innocent of any wicked Intentions
as the Child unborn God knows! pray tell me if I am ever
spoken of and how?- - -
You see I'm determined not to torment you with my Books
and gravity any anymore - I hope you don't think my Dear Girl
that I meant what I said about my Mother as any Reproach
or that I looked upon the sending of compliments as a necessary
Etiquette; no indeed what I said was merely from a wish
that you should feel interested for my family as I do for
your's - I long to see Mrs. Robinson's Verses -
as for Politico, Mum's the word - my father's to come home
tomorrow Oh joy and jubilee! -
How could you bestow six lines upon those wretched flow-
ers flowers which wer'nt worth six farthings -
As you were so kind to say How I long for your answer
I have prefered writing a speedy to a long one
parti-
-cularly
particularly
as all the family are gone to Bed - So adieu
my kind Friend and good Physician, preserve all
your sprightly freedom & good goodnatured sincerity and
sometimes think of her who often thinks of you

postscript.p:
I beg my Respectful compliments to Ld. and Lady Robinson
not out of form - for I'm thoroughly convinced that a mo-
ther mother who has given such an Excellent and successful
Education to her Daughter must be an amiable
as well as sensible Woman - My love & my Direction
to the new Hartley - answer Quick as I have done
In the dead of night no Mortal stirring!
What shall I do! I can't for the life of me find yr. I though I've
your letter under my hand.- Had I best send this without one or
not send it at all?- Pray don't be angry & I'll look for it all day tomorrow
